titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory of the Lee Edwards Papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff.

change.item: January 15, 2014: Incremental materials added November 18, 2013: Added reformatted audio

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards papers

physdesc.extent: 340 manuscript boxes, 7 card file boxes, 4 oversize boxes, 5 film reels

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, memoranda, reports, studies, financial records, printed matter, and sound recordings of interviews and other audiovisual material, relating to conservatism in the United States, the mass media, Grove City College, the Heritage Foundation, the Republican Party, Walter Judd, Barry Goldwater, and Ronald Reagan. Includes extensive research material used in books and other writing projects by Lee Edwards. Also includes papers of Willard Edwards, journalist and father of Lee Edwards.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Lee Edwards papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2010.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

relatedmaterial.p: Walter H. Judd papers, Hoover Institution Archives
Ronald Reagan subject collection, Hoover Institution Archives

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Edwards, a historian of American conservatism, has been the author or editor of over 20 books, including biographies of Ronald Reagan, Barry Goldwater, and Edwin Meese III, as well as histories of the Heritage Foundation and the conservative movement as a whole.

Edwards earned a doctorate in world politics from the Catholic University of America as well as a Bachelor of Arts degree in English from Duke University. He completed graduate work at The Sorbonne, Paris and received an honorary doctoral degree in humane letters from Grove City College.

An adjunct professor of politics at the Catholic University of America, Edwards was also the founding director of the Institute of Political Journalism at Georgetown University and a fellow at the Institute of Politics at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Edwards was also a media fellow at the Hoover Institution.

A frequently guest on cable and broadcast outlets such as Fox News, CNN, Bloomberg, NBC, PBS, C-SPAN and NPR, Edwards has also been published in the Wall Street Journal, Los Angeles Times, Boston Globe, National Review, Human Events and American Spectator.

Among his awards and honors are the Millennium Star of Lithuania, the Cross of Terra Mariana of Estonia, the Friendship Medal of Diplomacy from the Republic of China (Taiwan), the John Ashbrook Award, the Reed Irvine Accuracy in Media Award and the Walter Judd Freedom Award.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection contains a wide variety of materials documenting the life and work of Lee Edwards. Extensive research material used in books and other writing projects is included, relating to conservatism in the United States, the mass media, Grove City College, the Heritage Foundation, the Republican Party, Walter Judd, Barry Goldwater, and Ronald Reagan.

The collection also includes materials about the consulting firm Lee Edwards Associates, as well as documentation on Edwards' involvement in the Center for International Relations and Intercollegiate Studies Institute. In addition, personal papers of Lee Edwards, materials on his wife, Anne Edwards, and papers of Willard Edwards, journalist and father of Lee Edwards, are included. The papers include a variety of physical forms including correspondence, speeches, writings, memoranda, reports, studies, financial records, printed matter, sound recordings of interviews and other audiovisual material.

Lee Edwards interviews Grace-Marie Arnett on 12 Sep 1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This interview concerns the Heritage Foundation and the conservative movement.

Towards the beginning of the interview, Arnett goes out of her way to relate a story to Edwards. It concerns Carter in the 1980 election saying the Republicans are supposed to be the party that raises taxes out of fiscal responsibility and that the Democrats were supposed to be the party that knows how to spend that money. She says article she wrote about it went unpublished by her paper, but might be in the Carter library.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Marshall Wittmann on 15 Apr 1996
Lee Edwards interviews Marshall Wittmann on 18 Nov 1997

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This interview concerns Newt Gingrich. Wittmann is speaking largely off-the-record. Thus, while he is obviously respectful of and thinks highly of Gingrich, he details the shortcomings of Gingrich. He implies that being the leader of the majority changed Gingrich from the person that spent years learning in and leading the minority. He argues that Gingrich is trying to reshape the Republican Party in the way Franklin Roosevelt reshaped the Democratic Party. He then hypothesizes on what it will take to make Republican Party a long-term majority party.

did.unittitle: An Audio View: Echoes of the American Republic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sound recording contains commentary on the international and domestic events of early 1991. Topics include the roots of Patriot Missile in SDI, the economies of Eastern Europe, the banking industry, SAT scores, understanding Oliver North and the Iran-Contra affair, acid rain, conservatives, the liberal view of Ronald Reagan, the judicial system in China, military equipment in Europe, and British WWII songs.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Ross Foster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lee Edwards interviews Ross Foster about Foster's time at Grove City College, both as a professor and as a dean. Foster concentrates on how he and Pew turned the school around, bringing it back to its Christian roots. He argues the college is attractive as it offers a quality education at an affordable price and Christian values. He expands upon several specific reforms he made as dean and problems he observed as a professor.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Scott Peroell on 19 Nov 1998
Lee Edwards interviews Steve Balch on 16 Nov 1998
Lee Edwards interviews Tony Hall on 24 Aug 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This interview concerns Hall's experience as a student at Grove City College. Edwards interviews her at a time when she is actively seeking to transfer to a different school for academic reasons.

Among her criticisms of the academics, she does not believe the professors are knowledgeable of the field post-their-higher-education, citing the lack of professor requirement to publish. She believes the education is overly biased against leftism--an inverse of the contemporary stereotype of higher education. She finds the library woefully inadequate, citing her need to drive for two hours out-of-state to do her research.

Other topics include a campus-wide sexism against women both from professors and from students of both genders, students that are not Christian or heterosexual, the dorms, alcohol on campus, the transferring process, and the lack of female role models on campus.

Lee Edwards interviews Virginia Kadell on 11 April 1993
Milton Friedman speech on why he is not a conservative

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman speaks as part of a Cato Institute event at the Sheraton-Palace Hotel in San Francisco. He highlights that he, Hayek, and Gary Becker are liberals--not conservatives. Calling it a far better statement than his speech, he quotes parts of Hayek's "Why I Am Not a Conservative," which first appeared as part of Hayek's Constitution of Liberty.

Friedman is introduced by Ed Crane who notes that, while it is possible to argue about what economist had the most influence in the 20th century, no one can argue that anyone did more to spread the message of the free market system than Friedman.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Dorothy Bageant on 3 Mar 1989

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edwards interviews Dorothy Bageant about Dr. Walter H. Judd. While the conversation eventually briefly delves into questions of politics and policy, most of the conversation is about Judd as a person and employer. Though she believes it is difficult to sum him up in one word or phrase, she describes him as "scrupulously honest," "compassionate," "a good friend," and "very dedicated." Other topics of Judd as a person include his work ethic, skin cancer, and his proudest aspect was his MD degree, preferring to be called "Doctor" instead of "The Honorable."

As an employer, topics she covers about Judd are: when she went to capitol hill and how she met Judd, his final campaign for office, how he encouraged his staff to learn things because he wanted his staff to know what they were doing, a walk-through of a typical day, speaking on the college circuit, oral histories, when she stopped working for him, and how the Hill is now compared to when she was there. She says the environment is completely different, especially in regards to the Congressmen's employees not knowing important things about their Congressman, such as committee assignments.
On the policy side, she discusses Juddâs relationship with "big shots" such as Kennedy, Nixon, etc.; his papers; Nixon's offer to be on the ticket in 1960; and his relationship with Nixon in 1968.
Another, unrelated, program is also on the tape. It is a Spanish translation of an English-language speech (audible in the background).

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Larry Arnn and Milton Friedman in Aug 1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The interview with Larry Arnn is about the Heritage Foundation and other think tanks in the country. Arnn recounts how academia became politicized. The sound recording is not complete; the Friedman interview was likely taped over the Arnn interview.

The interview with Milton Friedman is a discussion of think tanks in America from the 1940s to the present. A woman, probably Rose Friedman, is audible in the background helping Milton. Friedman recounts his experiences with various institutions and individuals thereof including, but not limited to, the Philadelphia Society, the Mont Perelin Society, the Intercollegiate Studies Institute, and the Heritage Foundation. The conversation touches on Barry Goldwater, Bill Clinton, Bob Dole, Jack Kemp, and Michael Dukakis. Friedman believes the most important think tanks are the Hoover Institution, Brookings, AEI, Heritage, Cato, Frazier, and NCPA.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Leonard Liggio on 31 Jul 1997
Lee Edwards interviews Leonard Liggio on 8 Aug 2001

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lee Edwards interviews Leonard Liggio about the ISI. First they talk about its founder, Frank Chodorov as well as the conservative movement in the 1950s. People they talk about in the process are William F. Buckley, Jr., Robert Taft, and General MacArthur. Following Chodorov, the men then discuss Leonard Read, and E. Victor Milione.

In the second half, the men discuss the ISI and its successes. Liggio believes there are three good things the ISI has been responsible for: champing the Austrian school of economics, defending Western civilization against its internal enemies, and emphasis on the classics and Christian foundation. Edwards then asks what stimulates students' minds. This is followed by both lamenting the state of education, that students do not know how undereducated they are.
Third, they discuss Liggio's career in academia and miscellaneous aspects about the ISI.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Lew Lehrman on 13 Dec 1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edwards interviews Lew Lehrman about the Heritage Foundation and the conservative movement of the past fifty years.

On the conservative movement, Lehrman argues an important point is the history really begins with Coolidge and not Robert Taft. He asks Edwards to consider of adding a sub-theme of his book to counteract Schlesinger. Lehrman argues Reagan was the most important conservative of the past fifty years, and "pray[s]" that no one tells Edwards that Goldwater was the most important. Tying the conservative movement history to that of think tanks, Lehrman argues that Goldwater is to the AEI as Reagan is to the Heritage Foundation. He believes the most important turning points of the movement are the most obvious ones, but also stresses the collapse of the Keynesian consensus. He argues that universities cannot respond to collapse of institutions and change their worldviews because of tenure.

On the Heritage Foundation, Lehrman believes its work has been "very significant." He analyzes Heritage's takeover of AEI as the premier conservative think tank. Following, he stress the need for peaceful revolutions. He believes the board of think tanks should not be full of former heads of multinational corporations, comparing the two think tanks to illustrate his point. He points out that executives of established corporations cannot make big decisions that are very different from the interests of their corporations or without the approval of a board. He prefers a board made up of self-made (wo)men, arguing they can make major decisions very quickly and independently. He believes that think tanks still have a role to play, and constantly compares think tanks to the computer industry.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Loren Smith on 1 Apr 2002

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This tape is an interview with Loren Smith concerning the ISI. The interview begins by Smith describing how he became a political conservative during his college days. He says that in 1960 he was a Kennedy supporter, especially views on tax cuts and the missile gap, yet he was mostly apolitical before college. His political awakening was a gradual growth. To illustrate the growth, he mentions several people that influenced or helped him along the way. This leads into a discussion of his post-college jobs.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Newt Gingrich on 13 Feb 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edwards interviews Newt Gingrich about the Republican Party in the Twentieth Century. While Edwards was centering his interviews and book around a "big four" of Robert Taft, Barry Goldwater, Ronald Reagan, and Newt Gingrich. Gingrich counters that one cannot study the Republican Party in the twentieth century without analyzing Richard Nixon. Nixon was more influential for Gingrich than Taft. He goes on to explain why he favored both Reagan and Rockefeller over Nixon in 1968 and why he thought Nixon's approach was defeatist. Stating that he is standing on the shoulders of Reagan and Thatcher, they were not changing their party like he is changing the Republican Party to a less elitist organization. Gingrich comments on how he balances several roles (Speaker, leader of the Party, etc.), in the process explaining how Pete duPont was important to how Gingrich now works.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Newt Gingrich on 8 May 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The interview begins by Gingrich describing the political influences of his youth, how he came to his brand of Republicanism. Key influences he cites are a family leaning towards the Roosevelt wing of the Party, being in a Democratic state rifle with corruption, segregation and the civil rights act of 1964, and Ronald Reagan. He talks at length about Barry Goldwater and Richard Nixon, although he did not favor either, going just shy of using both as examples of what not to do. However, he feels his personal journey has been much closer to the journey of Nixon than Reagan. He thought Robert Taft was too abrupt with people.

On being a leader, Gingrich says he read over 500 books as a graduate student because he thought some people ought to know how to lead. When describing his rise to power, he details how the coalitions he built were different than those before.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews Steve Forbes on 3 Feb 1997

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edwards interviews Steve Forbes about the Heritage Foundation and the last fifty years of the conservative movement. Throughout the conversation, for both topics, Forbes delves into history to strengthen his arguments.

Regarding the Heritage Foundation, Forbes sees the organization as fulfilling the need of the conservative movement for ideas. He argues that prior to Heritage, there was no one quickly providing them with arguing points, data, etc. on a consistent basis. He argues the GOP and conservatives did not have the intellectual ammunition to counteract the liberals. Forbes brings up political events of the late 1960s and 1970s to illustrate his point: creation of the Congressional Budget Office, Nixon taking the budget office out of the Treasury, and the 1968 election. The conversation also touches on Ed Feulner and Heritage's work on tax ideas.

On the history of the conservative movement, Forbes calls Reagan the most important conservative of the last fifty years. He credits him with both the end of the cold war and the economic and technological boom of the 1980s. He says Reagan was what the GOP is not: optimistic and persuasive. He argues the party needs to control the political agenda better. This leads to an involved discussion on the political climate of the late 90s and what conservatives need to do better.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews T. Kenneth Cribb, Jr. on 4 May 2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The conversation begins discussing Cribb's biographical information. Cribb talks about his parents and how they influenced his personality. Included in this are religion, music, and literature. While going chronologically, early on the discussion sidesteps into a discussion of President Reagan's humanity. Cribb jokingly uses his college experiences to illustrate why there ought to be rules because, slightly paraphrasing, "until the age of 25, every important decision a young person makes is based on ignorance." Shortly thereafter, the conversation delves into a discussion of American conservatism vs. libertarianism/the English Whig philosophy, mentioning names such as Mises, Rand, Buckley, Frum, and Rockwell. The third part moves into the effect the Federalist Society has on the government. Cribb believes the future Borks and Scalias will come from the Society. The discussion then moves on to the funding and goals of the ISI. The end of the conversation links literature and the humanities to the goals of the ISI, regarding education, and touches on how the libertarian, Cato-esque view is different from Cribb's.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews William F. Buckley, Jr. on 12 Dec 1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edwards interviews William F. Buckley, Jr., about the conservative movement of the past fifty years, after briefly discussing Ed Feulner. Buckley says Reagan was the most important conservative figure over that time. He cites the following as turning points for the movement: Taft-Hartley, the conviction of Alger Hiss, Supreme Court court decisions, the election of Reagan, the fall of the Berlin Wall, and Bush on taxes. On the similarities and differences of Edwards' focal four figures (Taft, Goldwater, Reagan, Gingrich), Buckley argues Goldwater and Reagan were not that similar outside of being crowd pleasers. He also believes it is too early to speak about Gingrich. Other topics they cover are National Review, libertarianism vs. conservatism and the possibility of a purely-libertarian president, and the impact of computers are people's papers and records. Edwards concludes the conversation by saying the reason why conservatives won and liberals lost is that they rallied around two concepts: (1) communism was evil, and (2) the welfare state was out of control. Buckley adds a third point, a belief in a transcendent god.

did.unittitle: Lee Edwards interviews William F. Buckley, Jr. on 31 Oct 1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The interview is mostly a discussion of religion in America. Topics cover include why there were so many Catholics in opposing communism, the effect of the Religious Right and whether it is a good thing or not, separation of church and state, prayer in schools, abortion, the Pope, if Buckley ever wanted to be a priest, Dan Quayle, and the difference between Buckleyâs libertarianism and the Ayn Rand/Murray Rothbard-style libertarianism.
Aside from religion, Edwards asks if the country should be teaching values to its young, and he also asks if Buckley has a candidate for the 1996 election.
The second side of the original microcassette contains an interview with his brother. They focus on growing up with Bill and other family matters.

did.unittitle: Sound recording of a speech by Bill Bennett concerning the 1996 election and interview about the Heritage Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaking to a supportive audience, Bennett speaks about the upcoming election. He is critical about the Clinton administration, and he analyzes the Republican candidates.

In the interview, Bennett speaks about the Heritage Foundation. He believes what makes Heritage stand out is that it gets behind a person. He calls it the most important conservative public policy organization. He feels very good about the conservative movement intellectually. However, he says the movement needs to get beyond analysis and start to offer solutions. He further calls for conservatives to ween themselves off federal money, giving an example of financial aid for college to middle-class Republicans.

did.unittitle: Sound recordings of a discussion concerning publishing economics books, photographs of dignitaries, a day in the life of Walter Judd, and a discussion about China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

It seems to be a conversation about how to successfully publish and promote pro-free-market books, especially in Latin America.

Side B of the cassette has three distinct parts. In the first part, Edwards discusses photographs of "Walter" with various foreign dignitaries, many from southeast Asia. In the second part, Edwards asks Walter Judd (definitely Judd in this section) to describe a day in his life while a Congressman. During the discussion, Edwards audibly notes the cassette recorder was running out of battery power, and the sound quality is therefore lacking. The third part is Edwards with an unknown, Asian speaker talking about China.

did.unittitle: Sound recording of an ABC television program 20/20 on Barry Goldwater from 23 Jul 1993

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This program focuses on Barry Goldwater's view on particular issues. It starts by focusing on how his views on gays in the military, abortion, and the religious right are in conflict with the contemporary Republican Party. Other issues include his relationship with President Clinton, his views on Congress, Japanese companies, Ross Perot, and Goldwater's legacy.
It sounds like this sound recording was made by Edwards in his living room while he was watching the program. The sound quality is poor.

did.unittitle: Undated sound recording of Leonard Liggio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Liggio, of the Institute for Humane Studies, speaks in Vienna, Virginia.
An interview with Liggio follows on topics such as--but not limited to--libertarianism, conservatism, Murray Rothbard, and Ayn Rand.
